Serialized EMF model instances rely heavily on the ability to support cross document references in pretty much the same style as appears in standard .hmtl documents

relative references to anchors in other documents. Right now our ability to browse models in a CVS respository is extremely limited because starting with an IStorageEditorInput we have effectively no good way to turn that into a URI so the best we can do is something like this (from EcoreEditor):
* This is the method called to load a resource into the editing domains resource set based on the editors input.
// Assumes that the input is a file object.
// Load the resource through the editing domain.
we can create a platform resource URI of the form platform:/resource/<project-name>/<path-to-file> and load the resource for that URI

the URI converter is smart enough to recognize this scheme and will access the underlying IFile to read and write the contents.   The scheme is also registered as real URL so technically we could just use a URL
but that would bypass the IFile APIs (I think).  Relative references work nicely
because they are resolved against this absolute URI.
But for IStorageEditorInput we are a bit hosed.  The best we can do is get the input stream from that editor input object and load directly from that input stream.  Because there is no absolute URI
we cant resolve relative URIs within the stream.  And even if there was an absolute URI
wed need the ability to convert that URI to something we can use to access the stream in much the same way as we can convert a platform:/resource URI to an IFile.
I believe there is talk to define a URI in this type of form:
This will help a lot!  If such a thing would correspond to a real live URL handler
if you could create a URL for the above to get a stream

that would be good.  But an alternative would be for some type of mechanism that would allow EMFs URIConverter to be implemented in some other way. All thats really needed in the URIConverter is some way (any way) to take the URI and fetch its input stream.

The above URI form is not ideal though because a typical usage pattern is to use the URI for accessing the resource and append a fragment for accessing the contents within that resource.  So the URI for accessing the resource should avoid using the fragment.  This alternative would be effectively the same functionally but much better syntactically:
specify the path into the repository as the query string rather than the fragment so that a reference like this will work
